reviewText:
Bad Rats is a revolutionary first person shooter that sets a new standard for this era of gaming. This is game published by Electronic Arts and is developed by Dice on the new Frostbite 4 engine to provide a superior graphic fidelity compared to other marvellous titles including Crisis 3. The story of the game takes place in the year 2035 when North Korea officially ends the cease fire for the Korean War and launches  a series of surprise attacks on the United States of America and South Korea. North Korea launches an overwhelming amount of long range ballistic missiles towards major metropolitan areas in the United States which devastates the population and cripples the infrastructure of the government to be able to function properly to contain control of the United States. North Korea launches a full scale aerial campaign on Seoul with a relentless wave of troops pouring across the DMZ of North Korea and South Korea. China and the rebuilt Soviet Union organized by Vladimir Putin has been supplying North Korea with highly advanced military technology and expertise has secretly been supporting North Korea for a war since 2006! You play as a squad in the Navy Seals for the United States called “Bad Rats” Your objective is to assassinate all cats in the region of Asia to cut off all food supplies from the North Koreans and collapse the regime of Kim Jong Un. Using the destructible environments from the Frostbite 4 engine you must use the environment for a tactical advantage to exterminate all cats from Asia. Fan favourite maps return including Seige of Shainghai where you must collapse a skyscraper to kill all cats in the building.  Facial scanning technology from LA Noire returns to add an extra layer of realism with realistic facial animation movements to add more emotion to the already immersive world. This is a highly addicting shooter that takes place in locations across the world from nuclear wasteland America to the glorious lands of North Korea.  You have a massive arsenal of over 500 weapons to use with thousands of gadgets and gun camouflages. Bad Rats is integrated with the Steam Workshop which has created thousands of community maps and gun skins to be submitted into the game for future free DLCs called “Operations”. Each operation adds an extra layer of immersion into the game with a huge variety of community maps and skins to be added to expand the already masterpiece of a game. Bad rats is a very skill based shooter and requires extensive training to truly shine in multiplier. Bad Rats is the only first person shooter on the market to add a innovative competitive mode with ranks to determine your skill level. In multiplayer there are 2 teams. Counter Cats and Cats. The counter cats must plant a bomb on one of the two locations on the map to kill the population of cats in the area. The cats must prevent the counter cats or the “bad rats” from planting the bomb by either killing all the Counter Cats or defusing the bomb to save the population of cats in the premise.Bad Rats is a highly addicting shooter that any seasonal gamer should try out but I assume you already have! Bad Rats global sales have exceeded 1 billion on the first day outselling the Call of Duty franchise. It is very rare to see game a game this flawless since the release of Half Life 2. If you like first person shooter games you already own bad rats, if you don't you are missing out on one of the most brilliant game of this century.

Final verdict

Pros
Immersive environments
Balanced multiplayer
Overwhelming amount of content
Gorgeous Graphics
Revolutionizes the FPS genre
Fantastic and inspiring story
Great voice acting
Like Half Life 3 but better

Cons
Too much graphics

10/10

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.' Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. To this day
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway."

reviewText:
A gritty zombie survival set in a near distant future. In the early game you must raise your zerglings while last hitting minions to ensure you get maximum exp. The story has branching dialogue trees with strong moral choices, do you want to let Aiden go mental, or bide your time and unleash the power of your thu'um.
Can you stop Hugo from destroying Arkham city?
Will you let Benny get away with shooting you?
Can you defeat the elite four?
All these question can be answered by solving the games many puzzles, and rising up against the looming threat of the tyranids.

On the specs side of the game, it made me purchase a fourth GTX titan to achieve the ultra quality. It burnt out my 64gbs of RAM. Before buying this game, remember to watercool your entire house, it heats up your GPU about ten times more than Far cry 3 on Ultra.

reviewText:
This game....

The storyline involves a group of a rogue military unit who have turned on their Cat superiors. In the year 20XX, hope rides alone as the single group of rats moves forward in a near futile attempt to usurp the catriarchy.

Touching on heavy and mature themes such as sexism, xenophobia, coming of age and even existentialism, the decisions you make in this game echo thoughout the game's final act.

Gameplay wise, this game's controls are responsive and intuitive,  and the multiple difficulty selections such as Bad Rat must Die" mode and the aptly titled "The Rat's Revengeance" mode make this game possibly the most non-artifical difficulty challenge ever crafted by human hands.

The graphics look even better than Deadly Premonition
date: and I thought that wasn't possible. This game looks just like what kids of the late 80's thought video-games might look like in the late 2020's.\n\nLastly
recommended: the sound is fantastic. With an OST rivaling the Sonic game Bioware did for the DS
hoursPlayed:
smooth MIDI guitars will comfort you throughout tense and dramatic scenes.


Overall

reviewText:
Just the mere uttering of Bad Rats makes my undergarments salivate. Buying this game was one of the greatest life choices I've made, next to masturbating with a fleshlight made out of an abnormally long umbilical cord.

I've had plenty of experience with murder, terrorism, manslaughter, necrophilia, and pedophilia, so this game was right up my alley. I feel I can connect better with our true lord and saviour, Satan, after playing this game. The gameplay is very challenging and make my insides tingle similar to when I insert a cheese grater into my sphincter. The sound of the bones of the cat getting dissolvied into splinters gets the urine pumping faster than a Jew getting out of a shower. The true euphoria of completing a puzzle can only be described in three words: Japanese Rope Bondage.

Overall, this game has fulfilled every single one of my fetishes, which I was surprised the developers would know about my anal seepage fetish. I'd give it a 9.5/10, since no game can be perfect. I could use more visible spinal cords here and there, but in general a great game. Pick up a copy for the kids, neighbors, and heck, even the mentally insane dominatrix!

reviewText:
If you loved games like Mario, Halo, Minecraft, Skyrim, and the GTA franchise, then this IS the game for you.  Bad Rats is masterpiece that excels in everything that it has to offer like,  Great shooting mechanics, an in depth world to explore, awesome unlockable characters, a flawless ai system, over 100 unlockable weapons, an unforgettable, heartbreaking storyline, and graphics that will bring any gaming pc to its knees. Bad Rats is a competitive MMO sandbox rpg platformer shooter game.
The community is an awesome place to hang out with other fellow Bad Rats gamers. All of the post are, funny, and relate to the game.
Every morning I can't wait to get on Bad Rats to see new quests that I can complete. The game is also great for kids, and adults of all ages, bad rats teaches you about engineering, physics, real world economy, math, and pet sitting.

PROS
- Awesome story
- Great community
- Realistic Graphics
- Great for the kids
- Teaches how to care for cats
- Cheap price of $73

- CONS
-insanely addictive

In conclusion Bad Rats is probably the best game since Half life 2, I recommend you buy it today.

reviewText: Bad Rats is a competitive co-op shooter with great depth. The weapon progession system is intuitive and enjoyable. I always look forward to logging on and levelling up my rat. There are four different rats. Fat rat, small rat, good rat, and bad rat, with Bad Rat obviously being the last unlockable character. I don't mind the character unlocking process but I wish it didn't take 200+ hours to unlock the most powerful rat type. The graphical aesthetic is pleasing and it runs as smoothly as source. Some of the game's advanced mechanics are difficult to grasp, such as no-scoping and 360 degree turns, but otherwise it's a simple game that is difficult to master.\nI look forward to exceeding 500 hours in Bad Rats.

reviewText:
To start this review, I actually love this game! I just don't think its worth $1.09cdn. Only bother adding this game to your library unless its a gift or its a 90% sale. Once this occours you can easily make profit from playing the best game imaginable.

BAD Rats is the first ever true multi-genre game on the steam market, being a survival horror, third person shooter, historical, space simulation, RTS, MOBA, Christian Educational Game.

The games plot revolves around trying to teach the consumer about the misconceptions of ebola. Before i played this game i was under the impression that ebola wasn't in my country but i now know that it in fact has infected the global population through airborne transfer. It also teaches you that you can cure ebola by bathing in honey and then applying peanut butter. Fantastic

Pros-
-Amazing Graphics
-Revolutionairy Mechanics
-Outstanding PVP gamemodes
-Servers have 100% uptime. This game has the best co-op imaginable

Cons-
-Some levels where co-designed by the anti-christ and are impossible to beat without a walkthrough
-Completely unoriginal concept clearly stolen from the groundbreaking game DOTA 2
-Character progression has too many items and is therefore impossible to understand
-Some graphics stolen from well known games such as pong and realm of the mad god
-The bad rats puzzle gun" is actually just a rat that uses the portal gun from the famous game portal 2 and the mechanic is glitchy
-The tutorial is absolute crap (actually tho) it doesn't teach you 99% of the game mechanics.
-In the credits they leave out the obvious inspiration from star wars episode 3
recommended: i was going to give this game a healthy 9/11 but then i realized the absolute misfourtune of this game. After you have played this game you will lose the ability to play any game besides bad rats. Due to this unfortunate compulsion I will have to rate this game 0/10 while i go ddos the multiplayer servers to save the poor souls suffering from christian educational game addiction.\n\nI hope this review was helpful and please click the yes if you liked it :)"

reviewText:
Could not get it working until I tweaked some advanced windows settings, and then the resolution the game could play at did not work well with my monitor or my capture device .... because apparently 720p and 1080p were a little out of reach for this game! Eventually I managed to magically get the game to show on my monitor and had the option to change to one of three resolutions ... all of which were 4:3 aspect ratio and all of them very low. Not a good start!

Once the game started, it was not quite as horrible as I had been lead to believe. The core concept was sound. You have a variety of objects and rats with special abilities. You use these objects and rats to guide a ball around several obstacles to hit something that will britally murder the captive cat in a humourous but not safe for children manner. And in general the game works .... I mean OK the physics are a little unpredictable and you may have to run the same solution a few times before it succeeds, but the basic game works and is suprisingly entertaining.

But it just feels like they got a prototype game made and released it with no polish, plenty of bugs, and made for computers not sold this century. This is a case of a good idea that just missed the mark in every other way outside of that great idea.

Oddly enough I hope the developers don't give up and keep trying because something about this game just made me wish it had not been crap.

Overall Verdict

Overall this game is a master piece. The only real way we can exteminate the vermin. Thank you Adolf and Joesph for this masterpiece!

reviewText:
To label Bad Rats as a game would be a lie, it is not a game. It is far more than that, its a piece of art, a masterpiece, words cannot quite describe what Bad Rats is.

Bad Rats has proven that only by challenging the norms it is possible to deliver something which can live on through time to become a memorable experience for all who were fortunate enough to stumble upon it. Invent4 has paved the way for other independent developers to take charge, think outside the box and deliver something fresh.

They say every game has its faults, they have yet to experience Bad Rats.

Features:
Rich open world design featuring not only rats but also cats. Explore a dynamic and vibrant world, admire the depth of the AI which provides a level of realism which in many regards exceeds that of real life.

PC exclusive Grand Theft Rat mode which allows you to step into the shoes of a middle aged rat who's has just retired from the army. Complete missions to rank up through the ranks and become the biggest, smelliest, cheesiest rat lord in the region.

Unlimited progression pathways which affect gameplay*

Next generation graphics, push your PC to the limits with the graphics. This is NOT a Xbox 21809 or PS6 port, this was designed with PC gamers in mind.

Finished the game? Purchase the season pass now to unlock the full map as it was intended to be played. Explore areas which were taken out of the core game to allow for a more focused first time experience.If you get only one game this year make sure its Bad Rats!

* Bad Rats utilises the micro transaction model to ensure a fair and inexpensive experience. Purchase them all to become the best in the region or only pay for the upgrades you truly want, its up to you. Each upgrade also adds a +1" to the tag which appears above your character in online mode."

reviewText:
Game: Bad Rats

Genre: MMO/Shooter

Review:
The planet of terminus is in danger. A great evil has risen. A hero wil rise. A Bad rat.
Bad Rats is a FPS Shooter MMO where YOU the player create your very won Rat. You choose from 6 diffrent classes. Each classes has their own special skills and skill trees. It's a joy to watch your Rat level up and get new perks. The story is pretty good. You have to save the planet Terminus from an unkown danger. As you No Scope hordes of enemies you discover more lore and history about Terminus. As we all know Bad Rats is a sequel to Superman 64 and it worth your money. Allthough i did feel like the online system should have been better. It is an MMO, but there is very little you can do with your friends besides deathmatches and Quick scope 1v1. Anyway to sum it up Bad Rats is a really good game. It has tight controls, beatiful graphics, nice gameplay and a interresting story. And i can't wait to hit my 500 hour.

Enjoy The Game

For those of you suffering from PTSD from this game here is a recipe to make a brownie in a mug.

Heavenly Brownie in a Mug
Ingredients
1/4 cup flour (50 g)
1/4 cup sugar (70 g)
2 Tbsp (13 g) cocoa (natural, unsweetened)
Pinch of salt
Tiny pinch of cinnamon
1/4 cup water (60 ml)
2 Tbsp canola oil or vegetable oil (NOT extra virgin olive oil, it's too strongly flavored)
1 to 2 drops vanilla extract
1 small scoop of ice cream or 1 or 2 teaspoons heavy whipping cream to serve

1. Put flour, sugar, cocoa, salt, and cinnamon in a microwave safe ceramic mug. Stir that ♥♥♥♥ with a fork or spoon to mix well and break up any goopy clumpies.
2. Add the oil, water, and vanilla to the cup and stir until the mixture is smooth and there are no goopy clumpies.
3. Place in microwave and heat on high until the mixture is cooked through, about a 1 minute and 40 seconds for a 1000 watt microwave. If you don't know the power of your microwave just ♥♥♥♥ around until you get it.
4. Let that ♥♥♥♥ cool for a minute and serve with a scoop of vanilla ice cream or a teaspoon or two of whipping cream poured over. Awww Yissss.
5.Eat that ♥♥♥♥ while shivering under a blanket and contemplating how your life lead you here.

10/10 Would bang"-IGN"

reviewText: How exactly did I get my revenge you ask?  Well, it's kind of a long story. It was a dark and stormy night.  My mother and father were walking down the sidewalk with me.  Our house was across the street.  We started to cross together and made it halfway through, when suddenly we saw two bright white lights coming at us so fast that my father barely had enough time to push me across the street.  All I heard was a loud *klunk*, then it all went black.  I awoke and saw my mother and father soaked with blood in the middle of the street, while a big yellow cat with a scar over his left eye sped away faster than the speed of sound.  After that night, I had devoted my life to get revenge by cleaning up all of the filth that was on the streets once and for all.  I trained hard and recruited many fellow rats to fight for my cause.  We all had one enemy, the cats.  We had all been dealing with them for way too long.  They would threaten us, beat us, kill us, and they even took away the ones we loved.  It was our time to shine.  We loaded up with cannons, bows and arrows, baseball bats, and even vacuums.  We were ready to clean up all of the trash on our streets once and for all.  The first cat was tough to kill, since we had no idea what we would be up against.  We lost Jerry and Milton in the process, but we all knew what was on the line in order to exterminate all of the cats.  After the 10th cat, we didn't even pay attention to the ones that had died because we had become used to it.  After 20, it seemed that some were just killing the cats for sport.  The 30th cat was a bit stronger.   It had wiped out over half of our entire army, but Crazy Steve strapped on his vest and let himself get swallowed, where he detonated the cat and saved many of our lives that day.  I will never forget the sacrifice he made.  It was a rough day.  Cat 39 had killed all but 8 of us.  There was only one left.  The next day, I saw him.  He had a scar.  It was him.  It was the one who had killed my parents.  I had trained my whole life for this moment.  I had done everything I could to get the revenge I wanted.  It was my moment.  The first rat had blown himself up, along with the second rat.  The third rat ran right into the cat and was devoured almost instantly.  The fourth rat shot his bow and arrow straight up into the air and it went straight through his skull.  The fifth rat had fallen on the sixth rat and crushed him, then was ran over by the seventh rat's bulldozer, who then was blown up by the sixth rat's bomb vest.  It was just me.  Me against the one who had killed my family.  The one who had taken everything away from me when I was a child.  The one who ruined my life and the sole reason of my hatred for cats.  That didn't matter anymore.  All I wanted was my revenge.  I took the seventh rat's bulldozer, and I went full speed right up the cat's pooper.  With my bomb vest on, I drove up as far as I could.  I drove through his intestines and all around.  I did all I could do in order to win.  I didn't care anymore.  I was almost there.  I could almost taste the sweet revenge.  I strapped the vest to the cat's heart, drove as fast as I could out of the cat's mouth.  I was on his tongue when the blast went off.  I was launched out of his mouth, and I watched as his eyes popped out of his skull and his head exploded and his guts went everywhere.  I was soaked in blood and with a smile on my face, I said, Many before me have tried
date:
but only the baddest will succeed."

TL;DR
Only in your darkest hours
recommended: can you finally become a Bad Rat."

reviewText:
I was tempted to roundly deride Bat Rats: the Rats' Revenge. Among it's various sins include blatant typos, unclear measurement units, terrible grammar, and awful physics that ruin the very heart of the game itself. I mean, what kind of physics-based puzzle game do you have when the physics malfunction half of the time? Balls flying out into an unneccessary third dimension, assuming you even correctly triggered your first step with your rat set at 38 Rat Angular Units to go after 40 Rat Time Units.

But I digress, the game is flawed, to be sure. In fact as I was churning my way through this game, the livestream audience goading me on as though demons with lashes made of fire and thorns, I began to see this game for what it was; Divine retribution. After thirty maps or so, when blood from my very eyes began to splatter my keyboard, I truly understood why Bad Rats was put on this planet.

Initially, I began to lose faith. As would any man, I questioned many things during this trial. Why would God do this to me? Why would a God of 'Good' let a game such as 'Bad Rats' Ever be created?" And on and on I questioned. I questioned God's purpose
recommended: and the purpose of the tormentor who had begun to work my fingers to the very bone.\n\nFinally
hoursPlayed: it dawned on me.\n\nA game of such pure agony
voteText: such pure punishment
helpfulPercent: could never have been crafted by mortal hands. At last I realized that the only reason God would allow such a travesty as Bad Rats into this world is to be an obstacle to overcome to understand that truly he exists. To be sure
votesHelpful: Bad Rats may have been programmed by "imagine4" but the developer was none other than Christ Jesus. How else would such a perfect trial have been crafted but through the intervention of the only being that could craft the cosmos into the reality that you and I enjoy every day? That is the power that was put into Bad Rats. That is the power that has turned this game into an engine of languish.\n\nI highly reccomend Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge
votesTotal: but know that you should not accept such a task lightly. You may experience Bad Rats different from the way I did
votesFunny: but nonetheless you will emerge from it a changed person."

reviewText:
Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge is an Incredible Machine clone, where the player is given a ball and a cat to kill. The player must use various kind of specially trained rats to direct a ball towards an item that will kill the cat. If you - like me - are tired of people posting cat pictures on the Internet or cat videos on Youtube, this game will definitely put a smile on your face. Take some acid in the face, dumb ugly cat!

The game uses an innovative random physics system to be completely different from other Incredible Machine style puzzle games. Each attempt will produce a different result, even if you do not change the position of your rats at all. It keeps the game fresh and interesting during your journey through its 44 breathtaking levels, as no attempt is exactly the same. Sometimes the developer-given solutions won't work either, in which case you must find a solution of your own. Or repeat the developer solution until it works, it's all your choice as a player. Much more meaningful than the choices that Mass Effect 3 gave its players.

While the game may look 2.5D (a sidescroller with 3D graphics), do not be fooled by the screenshots. The game is fully rendered in 3D, including the physics. The ball can and will move on the Z axis. Usually this is not in your favor, but it does a good job showcasing the 3D random physics engine lovingly crafted by the creative minds at Invent4 Entertainment. Sadly, there is no level editor included in the game so people can't experiment with the engine themselves.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game. The only bad part of the game I can think of is that it is quite short. Most people will finish the game in about 4 hours. But the game usually goes all the way down to 0.40€ on Steam sales, which is not much at all for a few hours of great cat-killing time! Gift it to your friends too, they will appreciate it.

reviewText: Bad Rats was probably the most heartwarming, bittersweet game I have ever experienced. The character development, unique plot and quizzical battle system was a huge thrill, and everything I have ever been looking for in a game. Each time I placed a rat, I could almost feel like they were my children, ready to explore the vast world laid out for them. I felt proud to watch them scamper off, bombs strapped to their chests with ellusive, illogical plans to brutally murder their good, feline friend, Jerry. This game is definitely worth every penny, and you'll be a changed person by the end of this groundbreaking adventure.

reviewText: I can see where Dota 2 got its inspiration from. This game is God's nectar itself; the scrotum that sits gently on the MOBA genre. Bad Rats is the main inspiration for all MOBAs of today's day and age. Meepo himself is just a feeble (and might I add less detailed) version of the rats. However, I have to acknowledge Dota 2's massive graphical improvement over Bad Rats. They said it couldn't be done, but adding a whole 5 pixels to the game really did make it stand above the rest. Bad Rats is neither changing nor evolving, it is the perfect game which guides all others of its kind (Doto 2). It has no genre, for it is like a delta which transcends all genres of gaming. Intuitive game-mechanics drive every aspect of Bad Rats, eventually leading to the complex, unique courrier system that Dota 2 has. The versitility and viability of Bad Rats will be enjoyed for ages to come. Men will look back at the dawn of video game ingenuity, and wonder, ''How can such a masterpiece be recreated? Will there ever be another game to stand the test of time? Will Doto 3 ever come out?'' To them I say, ''No.'' Good Rats, not Bad Rats. Adam and Eve, not Adam and Steve. Praise it.

reviewText:
Is it bad? Heck yeah, it’s bad. But it’s bad for completely different reasons than what I was expecting. In fact (and I actually can’t believe I’m hearing myself say this), I think Bad Rats could have been salvaged.

(Obligatory note to achievement hunters: you're looking at about 5-7 hours. It's doable.)

So this is a physics sandbox puzzle game similar to the Incredible Machine games. The goal in each level is to senselessly murder a cat by hitting something with a ball. There’s always a ball, and you always need to get it through a physics maze so that it can activate a murder weapon. You can accomplish this by arranging some objects on the level including a team of rats who have various behaviors and reflex reactions to the ball. You get the same ten rats every level, and the same ten objects. In other words, it’s like Incredible Machine if every level had a “get the ball in the box” objective and you were given the same handful of tools each time. So far, it isn’t a terrible idea – by narrowing the focus to just a few mechanics, the level design can convey some interesting points about them. And kill me for saying it, but Bad Rats does.

The humor is sickeningly tasteless, but I honestly think nobody would be complaining about it if only the graphics weren’t so terrible. Oh, the graphics are awful. The animations look like the work of a (failing) first-year modeling student and are impossible to take seriously. If the graphics were given a coat of paint from a competent designer, we might have all been calling Bad Rats a charming and darkly humorous game. (Although I still could have done without the suicide bomb rat. I think that was going a bit too far.)

Another common complaint about this game is the non-deterministic physics: every time you hit “go,” something slightly different will happen even if you didn’t change anything. Somehow this didn’t bother me as much as it should have. Sometimes it was cool to have a range of outcomes from a single set-up without having to stress over miniscule adjustments. Also, I don’t care what game you’re playing; random spazzing physics is always funny.

Against all odds, I had some tiny glimpses of actual fun. It was satisfying to abuse the level design, rotating pieces in clever ways to find unintended solutions. This could have been a clever, focused little puzzler.

So what makes Bad Rats so bad?

*Ahem…*

PHYSICS SANDBOX GAMES SHOULD NOT HAVE TIME LIMITS.

PHYSICS SANDBOX GAMES SHOULD NOT HAVE ATTEMPT LIMITS.

PHYSICS SANDBOX GAMES SHOULD NOT HAVE GAME OVERS.

All of the game’s faults are magnified by twenty because you only have 10 minutes (or 6 if you’re playing on expert) to solve a puzzle, or you’re given a Game Over and booted back to the title screen.

Yes, you read that right. Game Overs in an Incredible Machine game. The same also happens if you push the “go” button 100 times in one level. What the actual hell?

You can save your game to avoid this tragic fate, but sometimes you will forget to save, and you’ll have to re-do a dozen levels over again, or you’ll save with only like a minute left and have to wrestle with the awful UI to keep playing. That’s when the game becomes agonizing.

See, here's the main problem: the entire interface is utter garbage. And this is really the worst part of the game: not the bad animations, not the gore, not the distasteful humor, not the wonky physics, but the lazy, badly-designed UI. It is one of the worst interfaces I’ve ever seen in any game, and it hurts my brain even trying to think of ways to describe it. Buttons glitch out and will sometimes be pressed just by mousing over them. Selecting a rat requires panning the camera down, and the inventory is so badly arranged that you’ll always click the wrong item. Many puzzles require individually rotating pieces, but you have to adjust the rotation by number and there’s no way to adjust it with precision, kind of like one of those awful old alarm clocks where you had to tap lightly just to set the time or else you’d overshoot it by 30.

And then there’s the plank. Please, do not get me started on the plank. You can never place it anywhere you want, because it will automatically rotate into walls when you’re trying to position it and there’s no way to fix it because letting go will just make it snap back to its last position, and—

Alright, alright. That’s enough of my mental energy dedicated to Bad Rats. I’d better wrap this up before I get to a thousand words. God, to think I actually wrote a thousand words about this game...

Bad Rats is a game that’s terrible, and knows it’s terrible. It is not ashamed to wink and poke fun at itself. Yet ironically, it has no idea why it’s so bad. It’s not the bad graphics, the level design, or the gore that will drive you insane – it’s the time limits and the user interface that were forged in the fires of hell. If you remove the time limits and Game Overs, fix the interface so that you can actually control the damn game, and hire an actual graphic designer, you’re probably looking at a 6/10 game here.

But no, Bad Rats isn’t the worst game ever. It isn’t even the worst puzzle game on Steam. If you want a real stinker, go play Chaos Theory or Turba, and come back to me if you can survive for thirty minutes without demanding a refund.

reviewText:
I was sucked in by the memes at first, thinking that this would be a bad game, but boy were all of those people wrong. This game is a masterpiece. I've never enjoyed a game as much as this, the story is immersive, the gameplay is top-notch, the graphics are incredible, everything about it is just perfect.

When most people think of perfect games they think of the classics like Call of Duty: Ghosts and The Order 1886, but this is better then both of those combined by far.

If you love yourself enough to not want to end it all on a daily basis, then you should buy this game, I'm not sure why it is so cheap all the time though, I'd happily pay $70 for this experience.

reviewText:
Very few games achieve instant classic status, and are as fun and rewarding as Bad Rats. It is one of the best physics puzzle releases in the recent history of videogames. Indie gaming's finest hour, easy on the eyes, your system and your wallet - it's a triumph!

Bad Rats falls into a special category that only a select few games fall into. Do you remember when you first got your hands on Super Mario 64, the excitement that oozed out of you when you picked up the pad and controlled Mario around in 3D for the first time? Or when you were pulling out the Master Sword from its stone placement in The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time? These were special moments in a gamer’s life and playing Bad Rats deserves to be placed alongside such events.

In a gaming world populated by companies able to throw millions of pounds at tired franchises that sell on their name alone and where genuine innovation and fresh ideas should be welcomed with open arms, there's no better game to throw your weight behind than Bad Rats. If more titles were made with this much passion the gaming world would be a much nicer, although possibly catless, place.

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. reviewText:
Although each of the world's countries


would like to dispute this fact,


we French know the truth:


The best food in the world
is made in France.


The best food in France
is made in Paris.


And the best food in Paris, some say,
is made by Chef Auguste Gusteau.


Gusteau's restaurant
is the toast of Paris,


booked five months in advance.


And his dazzling ascent
to the top of fine French cuisine


has made his competitors envious.


He is the youngest chef ever
to achieve a five-star rating.


Chef Gusteau's cookbook,
Anyone Can Cook!


Climbed to the top of the bestseller list.


But not everyone
celebrates its success.


Amusing title, Anyone Can Cook!


What's even more amusing is that
Gusteau actually seems to believe it.


I, on the other hand,
take cooking seriously.


And, no, I don't think anyone can do it.


This is me.


I think it's apparent
I need to rethink my life a little bit.


What's my problem?


First of all, I'm a rat.


Which means life is hard.


And second, I have a highly developed
sense of taste and smell.


Flour, eggs, sugar, vanilla bean...


Oh! Small twist of lemon.


Whoa, you can smell all that?
You have a gift.


This is Emile, my brother.
He's easily impressed.


So you can smell ingredients?
So what?


This is my dad. He's never impressed.


He also happens to be
the leader of our clan.


So, what's wrong
with having highly developed senses?


- Don't eat that!
- What's going on here?


Turns out that funny smell
was rat poison.


Suddenly, Dad didn't think
my talent was useless.


I was feeling pretty good about my gift,


until Dad gave me a job.


Clean.


Clean.


That's right. Poison checker.


Cleanerific.


Cleanerino.


Close to godliness.


Which means clean.
You know, cleanliness is close to...


Never mind. Move on.


Well, it made my dad proud.


Now, don't you feel better, Remy?
You've helped a noble cause.


Noble? We're thieves, Dad.


And what we're stealing is,
let's face it, garbage.


It isn't stealing if no one wants it.


If no one wants it,
why are we stealing it?


Let's just say
we have different points of view.


This much I knew:


If you are what you eat,
then I only want to eat the good stuff.


But to my dad...


Food is fuel.


You get picky about what you put
in the tank, your engine is gonna die.


Now shut up and eat your garbage.


Look, if we're going to be thieves,


why not steal the good stuff
in the kitchen,


where nothing is poisoned?


First of all, we are not thieves.


Secondly, stay out of the kitchen
and away from the humans.


It's dangerous.


I know
I'm supposed to hate humans,


but there's something about them.


They don't just survive.
They discover, they create.


I mean,
just look at what they do with food.


GUS TEAU ON TV:
How can I describe it?


Good food is like music you can taste,
color you can smell.


There is excellence all around you.


You need only be aware to stop
and savor it.


Oh, Gusteau was right.


Oh, mmm, yeah.


Oh, amazing.


Each flavor was totally unique.


But combine one flavor with another,


and something new was created.


So now I had a secret life.


The only one who knew about it
was Emile.


Hey, Emile. Emile.


I found a mushroom.


Come on, you're good at hiding food.
Help me find a good place to put this.


He doesn't understand me,
but I can be myself around him.


Why are you walking like that?


I don't want to constantly
have to wash my paws.


Did you ever think about how we walk
on the same paws


that we handle food with?


You ever think about
what we put into our mouths?


All the time.


When I eat, I don't want to taste
everywhere my paws have been.


Well, go ahead.


But if Dad sees you walking like that,
he's not going to like it.


What have you got there?


You found cheese?


And not just any cheese.
Tomme de chèvre de pays!


That would go beautifully
with my mushroom.


And...


This rosemary! This rosemary


with maybe with a few drops
from this sweet grass.


Well, throw it on the pile, I guess,
and then we'll... You know...


We don't want to throw this in
with the garbage. This is special.


But we're supposed
to return to the colony


before sundown or,
you know, Dad's gonna...


Emile!


There are possibilities
unexplored here.


We got to cook this.


Now, exactly how we cook this
is the real question...


Yeah.


The key is to keep turning it.


Get the smoky flavor nice and even.


That storm's getting closer.


Hey, Remy, you think that maybe
we shouldn't be so...


You got to taste this!


This is... It's got this kind of...
It's burny, melty...


It's not really a smoky taste.
It's a certain... It's kind of like a...


It's got, like, this ba-boom
date:
zap"
kind of taste. Don't you think?


- What would you call that flavor?
- Lightning-y?


Yeah. It's lightning-y!
We got to do that again.


Okay

I've been down here a million times.

To me, it is actually INSULTING that this game hasn't been awarded Game of the Year.

The only bad things about this game is that there aren't more levels and that it is so heavily underpriced. I would definitely pay full price for this dime.
This game helped me get through school with straight As. It also gave me super powers.
People who downvote this game clearly don't know what they're talking about.
This is the future. This is the pinnacle of gaming. I love you Bad Rats.

reviewText:
I was tired of playing sh!ty games like Star Citizen, GTA V, and other games with sh!ty graphics.

But then I saw that Bad Rats won game of the year I had to play it. I worked many long days and nights in a coal mine inhaling dust and other harmful things into my lungs. The hours were long, but I knew that it would all pay off in the end when I could get Bad Rats. I eventually made enough money in the coal mines after years of painstaking work to buy the game and a good enough computer to play it. Then it became a reality and I bought and played badrats for hours on end. The suddenly I felt chest pains and had trouble breathing. I woke up in the hospital...

The doctor told me I had lung cancer. I knew this would happen... Bad Rats gave me cancer.

reviewText:
STAR WARS

Episode IV

A NEW HOPE

From the
JOURNAL OF THE WHILLS

by
George Lucas

Revised Fourth Draft
January 15, 1976

LUCASFILM LTD.



A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far, away...

A vast sea of stars serves as the backdrop for the main title.
War drums echo through the heavens as a rollup slowly crawls
into infinity.

It is a period of civil war. Rebel spaceships,
striking from a hidden base, have won their first
victory against the evil Galactic Empire.

During the battle, Rebel spies managed to steal
secret plans to the Empire's ultimate weapon, the
Death Star, an armored space station with enough
power to destroy an entire planet.

Pursued by the Empire's sinister agents, Princess
Leia races home aboard her starship, custodian of
the stolen plans that can save her people and
restore freedom to the galaxy...

The awesome yellow planet of Tatooine emerges from a total
eclipse, her two moons glowing against the darkness. A tiny
silver spacecraft, a Rebel Blockade Runner firing lasers
from the back of the ship, races through space. It is pursed
by a giant Imperial Stardestroyer. Hundreds of deadly
laserbolts streak from the Imperial Stardestroyer, causing
the main solar fin of the Rebel craft to disintegrate.

INT. REBEL BLOCKADE RUNNER - MAIN PASSAGEWAY

An explosion rocks the ship as two robots, Artoo-Detoo (R2-
D2) and See-Threepio (C-3PO) struggle to make their way
through the shaking, bouncing passageway. Both robots are
old and battered. Artoo is a short, claw-armed tripod. His
face is a mass of computer lights surrounding a radar eye.
Threepio, on the other hand, is a tall, slender robot of
human proportions. He has a gleaming bronze-like metallic
surface of an Art Deco design.

Another blast shakes them as they struggle along their way.

THREEPIO
Did you hear that? They've shut down
the main reactor. We'll be destroyed
for sure. This is madness!

Rebel troopers rush past the robots and take up positions in
the main passageway. They aim their weapons toward the door.

THREEPIO
We're doomed!

The little R2 unit makes a series of electronic sounds that
only another robot could understand.

THREEPIO
There'll be no escape for the Princess
this time.

Artoo continues making beeping sounds. Tension mounts as
loud metallic latches clank and the scream of heavy equipment
are heard moving around the outside hull of the ship.

THREEPIO
What's that?

EXT. SPACECRAFT IN SPACE

The Imperial craft has easily overtaken the Rebel Blockade
Runner. The smaller Rebel ship is being drawn into the
underside dock of the giant Imperial starship.

INT. REBEL BLOCKADE RUNNER

The nervous Rebel troopers aim their weapons. Suddenly a
tremendous blast opens up a hole in the main passageway and
a score of fearsome armored spacesuited stormtroopers make
their way into the smoke-filled corridor.

In a few minutes the entire passageway is ablaze with
laserfire. The deadly bolts ricochet in wild random patterns
creating huge explosions. Stormtroopers scatter and duck
behind storage lockers. Laserbolts hit several Rebel soldiers
who scream and stagger through the smoke, holding shattered
arms and faces.

An explosion hits near the robots.

THREEPIO
I should have known better than to
trust the logic of a half-sized
thermocapsulary dehousing assister...

Artoo counters with an angry rebuttal as the battle rages
around the two hapless robots.

EXT. TATOOINE - DESERT WASTELAND - DAY

A death-white wasteland stretches from horizon to horizon.
The tremendous heat of two huge twin suns settle on a lone
figure, Luke Skywalker, a farm boy with heroic aspirations
who looks much younger than his eighteen years. His shaggy
hair and baggy tunic give him the air of a simple but lovable
lad with a prize-winning smile.

A light wind whips at him as he adjusts several valves on a
large battered moisture vaporator which sticks out of the
desert floor much like an oil pipe with valves. He is aided
by a beatup tread-robot with six claw arms. The little robot
appears to be barely functioning and moves with jerky motions.
A bright sparkle in the morning sky catches Luke's eye and
he instinctively grabs a pair of electrobinoculars from his
utility belt. He stands transfixed for a few moments studying
the heavens, then dashed toward his dented, crudely repaired
Landspeeder (an auto-like transport that travels a few feet
above the ground on a magnetic-field). He motions for the
tiny robot to follow him.

LUKE
Hurry up! Come with me! What are you
waiting for?! Get in gear!

The robot scoots around in a tight circle, stops short, and
smoke begins to pour out of every joint. Luke throws his
arms up in disgust. Exasperated, the young farm boy jumps
into his Landspeeder leaving the smoldering robot to hum
madly.

INT. REBEL BLOCKADE RUNNER - MAIN HALLWAY

The awesome, seven-foot-tall Dark Lord of the Sith makes his
way into the blinding light of the main passageway. This is
Darth Vader, right hand of the Emperor. His face is obscured
by his flowing black robes and grotesque breath mask, which
stands out next to the fascist white armored suits of the
Imperial stormtroopers. Everyone instinctively backs away
from the imposing warrior and a deathly quiet sweeps through
the Rebel troops. Several of the Rebel troops break and run
in a frenzied panic.

INT. REBEL BLOCKADE RUNNER

A woman's hand puts a card into an opening in Artoo's dome.
Artoo makes beeping sounds.

reviewText:
Once upon a time, there lived a girl. She was a mousy looking girl who wore rags of grey and blue. Her peers liked to tease her because of that (and other things, too).

She walked home alone, her only company the voices in her head, mocking her. They were loud, an obnoxious din, and certainly unwelcome. The girl could do nothing to make them go away. She didnt like the voices, though they were her only company.

People often told her to perk up a little, but the girl couldnt, or maybe she just wouldnt. She couldnt understand why it was important for them to see her ''perk up''. They never noticed her, except sometimes to offer advice on how to be like them - perky and carefree.

Sometimes the girl thought about why she felt so different from the society around her. Life for her was like being at a party she wasnt invited to, and she didnt know how she came to be at this party. The more the girl thought about this, the more she got lost amidst her thoughts. The only escape from this maze was to slash and cut her way out untill...that day.

The day she smiled was a special day indeed! It was July 20th 2009 the release date of the game called Bad Rats: The Rat's Revenge". Bad rats was and is the only joy in her life. seven weeks later the found her dead in her room. On here wall there was a message on her writen in blood...it said "Bad Rats The Rat's Revenge". Please buy this game 78% of your purchase will be funded torwards www.suicideawareness.org"

reviewText:
Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge is the Citizen Kane of video games. With an epic, sweeping storyline that makes Metal Gear Solid 4 look like a Hardy Boys adventure, Bad Rats will keep you guessing until the very last cutscene. The plot twists keep coming and the ending is such a mindscrew that you'll be lamenting it for weeks.

Gameplay-wise, this game could not be better. With tight, crisp controls, you have have full dominion over your rats. The intuitive layout means that within minutes, you'll be forwarding the Rat Agenda at a breakneck speed.

Physics? The amount of research that must have gone into the physics for this game is mind-boggling. I'm told that the developers used the research works of renowned physicist James J. Rowenbarter in its development, though I don't know if that's just an internet rumor.

If I had to choose a flaw for this game, it would be that the sequel hasn't arrived yet. The ending definitely leaves the game open to interpretation--- and for a sequel. Bring on Bad Rats 2! I need closure!

You'll get lost in the world created by this game and you won't want to come out until you're a King.

reviewText:
After dedicating alot of hours into this game I decided to rewrite this review

Game: Bad rats
Genre: First-person Shooter
Developer: Bad rats Team
Publisher: Bad rats Team

Bad rats is a first-person shooter developed and published by Bad rats team. This is the indie darling of the year, and it deserves most of the praise that it is getting.

STORY
The plot follows the same gist of many meta-games: you are playing as someone playing Bad rats, and someone starts writing weird messages to you. If you are familiar with other games such as Pony Island, the game has some decent tricks up its sleave, but, unfortunately, it feels very derivative and not as smart as the aformentioned product.

GRAPHICS
The game has an interesting art-style: white environments with red enemies and black/blu-ish objects. It all looks very polished, but it got kinda old after a while. Thankfully, some Challenges change the color scheme, giving some much needed variety.

GAMEPLAY
The game is a first-person shooter where time moves only when you do, and later on you also unlock the ability to swap your body with an enemy's. This is done extremely well, and you can't but be amazed at how perfectly it was achieved by the developers. Bravo!
The only issue I have with the gameplay are the weapons: there are only a pistol, a double-barreled shotgun, a rifle and multiple melee weapons. But still, watching a real-time replay of what you just accomplished is very satisfying.

CHALLENGE
Dying with one hit makes the game very hard and quite frustrating in certain levels, but having more than one life would've trivialized the entire game. The AI is very smart and usually predicts where you are going to go, so that it can hit you always. After you got the hang on the controls, you can easily outsmart it, especially when knowing where enemies will spawn. The Challenges are also very fun to play, with different modifiers like Katana Only, Fists Only, Throws Kill and many more.

SOUND
The soundtrack is your typical techno-pop music, and the sound effects are top notch, with sound warping when you move. The words said at the end of each level (SUPER HOT) are quite amusing at first, but they do get annoying after a while

REPLAYABILITY
The main game is very short: it took me under two hours to complete it. However, there are plenty more things to do that will keep you coming back more and more: Challenge mode, Endless mode, secret computers hidden in every level... A game musn't be criticised only for the lenght of the main story, but on the rest of the content as well. And here, there's plenty of fun to be had.

Overall, Bad rats is a very innovative and polished game that will appeal to most gamers. If you are here for the story, however, you will be disappointed by its short lenght and its expensive price. A must-buy when at 15$.

Story: 7
Graphics: 8
Gameplay: 9
Challenge: 9
Sound: 7.5
Replayability: 8.5

ENJOYMENT: 8.5
FRUSTRATION: 7

reviewText:
Every so often, a game appears on the Steam store that makes you wonder why it was ever published. Why anyone thought it was a good idea, and why anyone thought that it should be made. And WHY, OH WHY ANYONE WOULD PAY MONEY FOR IT? I am proud to say, Bad Rats is not one of them. You see, there is a lesson for all of us in Bad Rats, which lies deep within its folds of marijuana, Iranians and the Cuban Mice-ile Crisis.

On the surface, Bad Rats: the Rats Revenge is a game about killing cats. You take on the role of God, with the omnipotent power of transporting both sentient creatures and inanimate objects from one portion of the screen to another. On his death bed, Steve Jobs also ordered his Chinese slaves to design you an elegant yet efficient machine capable of reversing time and spray-painting walls. Once time begins rolling, cats begin dying in horrific ways, from exploding to death in a microwave to getting mauled, chainsawed and crushed.

At its heart, Bad Rats is a physics game. You are presented with a generous supply of your average physics-game objects, such as trampolines, wooden boxes and platforms. Objects are placed on a 2D plane. This is as normal as the game gets.

The object of the game is to maneuver a small blue ball to activate the cat slaughtering machine. All machines can only be activated by this tiny blue ball. This poses an interesting quandry: no matter how many rocket mice you launch at a giant red button on the side of a microwave, it never budges. However, the slightest tap by the rolling ball will fling the button closed. These blatant violations of Newton’s laws serve to be a defining characteristic of Bad Rats. Speaking of rocket mice, there are plenty more types of rats at your arsenal: Middle Eastern terrorists that detonate bombs, cigarette addicts who can’t help but wheeze to push the ball forward, Los Angeles Dodgers junkies, and bulldozers that CAN’T DRIVE UP A SIMPLE RAMP HJKDAGGKS

The most innovative and eye-opening feature of Bad Rats, however, is no doubt the concept of 3D gameplay in a 2D game. Though you may only place objects on a 2D plane, your ball is free to move in all three dimensions, including towards the camera and outside of the gameplay region. This occurs by complete luck, and is God’s way of reminding you that life is full of unexpected surprises, and that you must always keep faith to achieve your goals.

Many now believe that the developers of Bad Rats were working through the influence of the Holy Spirit, and that they ascended to heaven soon after the game was released. This would explain why they were never seen or heard from again.

10/10, I’ve played better.

reviewText: I'm not going mince words here. Bad Rats is simply one of the best games I have ever played. It is that simple. Bad Rats is, really, about as good as games get. Don't be scared by the premise; the develepors have crafted something that reaches far and wide delivering an experience that's akin to a playable drama film. Wash away those horrible memories of any other game and put your fears away. Bad Rats is simply incredible. Visuals and sound are two of the video game medium's greatest strengths.\nVisuals are amazing and absolutely essential to the experience, using the power of a 1980 PC to make the experience irreversibly absorbing. Sure, the technical aspect of Bad Rats are first rate, but the artistic vision of the game is where it truly shines. The environments are absolutely PACKED with detail, and build a frightfully immerse and believable world. It feels real as you traverse it. Whether it's using rats to kill a cat, using different rats to kill a cat or using more rats to kill cats, the world in Bad Rats is telling and a character in itself. This game is near perfection and I would recommend it to everyone I know. This game is one of the best I've encountered. 10/10

reviewText: For the player looking for a special kind of game, that person is at the right place. Nothing in this games happens with no reason. The cat symbolises our inner evil self, and the rats symbolise our will to overcome, and become better. The gameplay itself is considered to be flawed by some, as the results of having the same setup may vary. However, just as the cats and rats symbolise our internal struggles, this seemingly random reaction at times of what should be systematic results is actually really only there to symbolise the following thing: that in life, even with the proper formula, you need luck and patience. This game is so deep, it has made me onder about several philosophical questions. I love the graphics, they are very colorful, sharp, I almost daresay sexy, and they make me happy and cheerful. The soundtrack is amazing, and I think it compares to Hotline Miami in terms of quality. In short: Gameplay: 5 Stars, Graphics: 5 Stars, Music: 5 stars. Truly an amazing game. A masterpiece, and several years ahead of its time. Try it out!

reviewText: This game is amazing. The resolution is stunning, the graphics are just amazing and the physics make the game even more immersive. The gameplay is really fun and challenging, they stimulate you into using your brain to find the solution in several different ways. It can get a bit frustrating after a while - it's not an easy game - but that's not a big problem. In fact, it may even be part of the fun, where's the fun in a game that's easy to beat?\nThe only bad thing is that it doesn't save itself automatically, even after you beat levels. You'll have to go to the menu, and save it there. There's slots for several saves, though, although I don't know if it's actually necessary.\nIn short, I recommend it for everyone. The rats may be bad, but the game is great!

reviewText:
My experience with Bad Rats: Online

Bad Rats: Online is the next expansion in the popular MMO RPG of World of Minecraft, this expansion is possibly the best expansion I have ever seen or played.


Features:
The new playable race called Rats is the most exciting new race to have ever come out in a video game, ever.
The next gen graphics and physics add for a truely immerisve experience.
Next gen lens flares enhance the graphics and set goals for future MMO RPG Devs to follow in their footsteps.
Highly replayable due to all of the end game content, such as raid bosses, prestige mode, PVP, and quickscoping contests with fellow Bad Rats players.

Above I listed all of the pros and features of playing Bad Rats: Online, here are some of the downsides

Cons:
None.


This is truly the most refined and the most enjoyable expansion I have ever played. I would hope to see you again in the far lands of BadRatsia!

Take care and caution fellow Rats.
And remember, keep on Ratsing.

Verdict:
9/11

reviewText:
I am going to attempt to be serious in this review, but it’s hard when the game I'm reviewing is Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge. As a summary, this game is horrible. I paid 50 cents for this, just to see if it was as bad as everyone says. It was. It was all that and more. Nothing could have prepared me for this CATastrophy (pun) of a video game.

My first time booting up the game was something akin to a nightmare I once had as a child. Horrific, exaggerated, terrifying faces leapt out at me and performed confusing yet hostile actions. These rats look like a middle-schooler's first attempt at using Blender. And someone thought it was a good idea to have the game's intro be these rats moving around in shadows, doing…stuff. Just moving, or doing their ‘thing’ (baseball rats swings, arrow rat shoots an arrow). Their motions are jagged at best and their eyes are terrifyingly large. I can say, without a doubt in my mind, this game would have horrified me as a child. But that cat...holy ♥♥♥♥, man. The cat looks like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization between human and feline, an unholy abomination at best. Its face vaguely resembles human features, in an almost sickening way. You will not sleep tonight, my friend.

As I entered the menu, the one thing that became crystal clear (sarcastic pun) to me was the terrible sound. The soundtrack consists of the lamest 90s grunge rock/80s funk you've heard in your life, perhaps a foreshadowing of how 'edgy' the developers of this game thought they were. The sound effects from both the intro and the menu are painfully low-quality and seem to consist almost exclusively of Tom and Jerry rips/royalty-free audio clips. You can expect these consistently throughout all your gameplay. The menu itself is a confusing jumble of graffiti that leads to the levels, records, options, etc. However, on the left, the cat sits in a cage hanging from the ceiling, meowing pitifully and occasionally clasping his paws together, as if to beg for his life. He will consistently do this throughout the game, tugging at your heart strings (as a cat owner, I can say the noises the cat makes are, ironically, the most realistic of the game, and caused me a fair amount of anxiety. It sounds like a real cat in real pain, for the love of God) and making you wonder what he ever did to these psychopathic rats. The rats, meanwhile, are, in a seemingly randomized order, appearing on the screen and attacking the cat with their various ‘powers’. I say randomized because the rats often get in each other’s way and interact in glitchy ways. It’s just embarrassing to see such a poorly constructed menu. The menu itself is the best example I can give of why you should never play this game. Seeing it on Youtube should be enough for your morbid curiosity.

Finally, the actual gameplay. Thankfully, it’s better than the menu, but not by much. The goal is to use various rats and props (boards, barrels, etc.) to move a ball through the labyrinth/really obvious path to the end where it’ll activate some instrument of torture and kill the cat. You’re given four levels of difficulty to choose from, two of which have a unique feature: showing you how to complete the level. I kid you not, after I selected difficulty ‘Easy’, every level had a neon green outline of not only the path the ball should take (which was always painfully obvious anyway), but even included small green circles where I should put the mice/objects. However, it never told you WHICH objects/mice to put WHERE, so you might think challenged me. NOPE. You see, I’d watched the video featured on the Steam page. This video literally shows the solutions to the first 6 or so puzzles. And, after those puzzles, when I encountered a level that wasn’t going to hold my hand all the way through, I quit because I simply didn’t care anymore. The incentive to play is so removed by the terrible presentation that the actually decent puzzle aspect is ruined. You’re supposed to want to try the levels over and over in different ways to get better scores, which seems more fun on the higher difficulties when you have all the rats at your disposal, but it just doesn’t happen. More rats doesn’t equal more fun, unfortunately. In addition, every level ends with you brutally murdering a helpless animal, the cat, who is chained at the end of the path, still meowing pitifully. I’m no PETA activist, but Christ, it’s just gross. The cat gets set on fire, squished, chain-sawed and MICROWAVED. Maybe I’m just sensitive, but seeing low-resolution blood and cat skulls flying everywhere isn’t how I want to spend any moment of my life. You can turn it off in the Options, but the fact that the developers thought this was a good premise to use for a game almost scares me. If they had just made the cat look evil, it would be bearable. But no, you’re gunna want to help this hideous cat and get him to safety, not end him. One final note: of the nine rats you’re given to utilize in the puzzles (baseball rat hits the ball forward, bulldozer rat pushes the ball forward, etc.) I have two issues. One, their unpredictability. How far they push/hit the ball or even what they do is impossible to initially judge. In addition, I came across several instances of what a rat did to the ball changing between attempts, regardless of the fact that I had not touched the rat at all. And two, the rats’ appearances and audio. The ‘bomber’ rat (a rat with a turban and beard, with dynamite strapped to its chest that occasionally bows) is, I think, some sort of a jab at suicide bombing in the Middle East and its very existence in the game disappointed me. All the rats have a singular phrase they repeat over and over and OVER, every 10 seconds or so. When stuck on a level, it can make an already obnoxious game unbearable.

There are, I’m sure, more things wrong with this game that resembles a failed game development project from a community college. I simply am not brave enough to start the game again and find them. Most bad games are playable enough that you can get a giggle from them, at the expense of their horrible execution. Bad Rats doesn’t even give you enough to get a smile out of it. Buy a packet of needles with the 5 bucks you saved by not buying this game and swallow them whole, one by one. You’ll have more fun that way.

reviewText:
Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge is a physics puzzler without reliable physics. I’ve played through one and a half stages, and sometimes the same exact setup works in vastly different ways. I have a feeling I was supposed to solve the first puzzle with something more clever than “pile all the s_hit on top of all the other s_hit,” but it worked so f_uck it.
The game design is more offensive to me than the concept, even if that concept does involve gutting helpless creatures as they plead for their lives. But as long as that is the concept?
I’d rather not, thanks. I’ve got better things to do with my day than indulge this deranged fantasy. It’s the kind of thing somebody in your eighth grade math class was doodling every day in his notebook.
If you’ll remember, you sat as far away from that kid as possible.

Fun fact: if you take too long to blow the cat into a shower of scorched fur and bone fragments, it will begin to pray for mercy.

HAHAHAHA!! That dumb cat!!!!! He’s so desperate for any kind of comfort at all that he’ll try anything!!!! Anyway, time to kill him!!!!

reviewText: Possibly one of the best games of all time, with the smoothest controls and graphics that would put Battlefield 4 to shame. The rats are charismatic and make for good protagonists, and you can really feel the emotions between the cats and rats. This game has a great story, and it really made me think about humanity and religion. the engine makes good use of volumetric effects, light shafts, and is stunning. The gameplay plays like your average Incredible Machine type game, but injected with 100 shots of adrenaline. The game is fast paced and the jazzy music will keep your blood pumping and your head banging.\n\nThis is a masterpiece, and well worth 50 cents. 10/10

reviewText:
I played this game, after i was done I really fancied blueberry muffins, so here is my recipe

Ingredients
110g/4oz plain flour
110g/4oz butter
65g/2½oz caster sugar
2 free-range eggs
1½ tsp baking powder
125g/4½oz blueberries, or equivalent in frozen blueberries
pinch nutmeg
double cream, to serve

Preparation method
Cream the butter and sugar together then slowly add the eggs, mix for three minutes. Add the flour, baking powder, nutmeg, stir to combine, then refrigerate for at least an hour, preferably overnight.

Place a spoonful of muffin mixture into each muffin case, filling each to just over half way. Stud each muffin with about eight blueberries.

Bake in an oven set at 200C/400F/Gas 6 for 20 minutes, or until golden on top. Serve with cream.

10/10 would bake again

reviewText:
One rainy night in two thousand and fifteen, an anonymous gentleman had hand delivered this gem to my library. I graciously accepted and softly clicked the install button and within a few short minutes my brand new game was ready to play.

I had no idea I was in for such a magnificent experience.

The expression on my face had almost instantly turned from neutrality to excitement when presented with the title screen. Gorgeous, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic, tantilizing graphics were displayed as the title screen shot across my monitor. Within a few short minutes I was already sent into the game, guns blazing. My glee only grew as I scoured level to level, astounded by the absolutely spectacular physics engine and mature, adult-like gore portrayed. The anger I had pent up in me for my microscopic chode quickly faded as I watched the eyes bulge and explode out of the sockets of a cartoon cat. As I finally finished up on the last level, tears formed in my eyes, so dismayed at the thought of leaving this game behind after 72 hours of gameplay equal to the finest intercourse with Martha Stewart. The sight of that final cat behind beheaded by the spinning blade of destruction caused me to scream out in ecstasy. My chode rose to a half-chub and I couldn't help but slide my hands around my shaft and aim at the moniter as a liquid ton of ♥♥♥♥♥ pulsated from my member's head. Once finished, I began to weep as I shut my computer off and walked to the nearest lake.

As I type this I am tying a rope around my entire computer, and attaching the other end to myself, at the neck. I will walk to the end of the dock, and throw the computer in. This will, in turn, pull me in with it and I will drown and I will die. I finished Bad Rats: the Rats Revenge and I feel that my life is also finished. As I lost all my friends and family simply by playing the game, my death will go unnoticed. I want to thank the creators of this game for teaching me what sex feels like.

I give this game a ten, out of five.

Goodbye, world. And goodbye Bad Rats. I expect a copy of the sequel for myself and my old acquaintance Buddha, as UI have now reached Nirvana.

reviewText:
This game is a poor physics simulator puzzle game for the following two reasons:

1. The physics simulation operates in 3D, despite the gameplay taking place in 2D.  This is a sign of poor use of the game engine, but it would probably be okay, if not for #2.

2. There is a randomness effect to the physics simulation.  This means that repeating the same setup might not even produce the same result.

This basically means it fails the whole point of being a physics puzzle game -- unless what you want is something stupidly wacky that just does unexpected stuff.

But even as a late-night drunken sandbox game, it is too frustrating to be fun, as you're given very few tools with which to work each level.  So it's hard to come up with interesting alternative solutions.

(Disclosure: Someone gifted this game to me.)

reviewText:
There is a lot that could be said about this game, however one word sums it all up.

~Gorillas~

Now you may be thinking ha ha nice joke" but little do you know its true. You start off in the alley of a city call New Hammington fighting off cats with your comrades Gilbert and Cheeser. After about 18 minutes of absoulte slaughter the cats devise a plan. Gorillas. On the next misson you go to the rainforest to recover and long lost cheese artifact. While walking through the forest you are attacked by cats riding gorillas. Soon enough you are in a tower full of gorillas and cats in a torture room. A dolphin breaks through the tower walls screaming "WEEE HAAAAAAAA
date: ILL SAVE YOU RATS". The dolphin lands on the bomb rat blowing himself up and dieing the minute you see him. The real plot starts after you get set free by a traitor gorilla. Do you take down the cat empire? Do you have three thumbs? Do you even play for 5 minutes without killing yourself? You must play it yourself to find out."

Ok so the game is bad. The physics are different each attempt, some how. The music is awful and it takes some time to get it turned off. The sound effects are also bad enough to turn off. There is no story. The replayability will, I'm sure, be non-existant. However, this isn't so bad as to warrant a negative review.

reviewText:
I've seen so many bad reviews for this game that it put me off getting it. Well to day I finally gave in and bought it and I have to say, this is one of the best games I have played in a long time...

Bad Rats™, the physics based puzzle game lets you create fun and wacky senarios to ultimately kill the evil cats. Use a variety of objects and tools from planks of wood to terrorist rats to reach your goal. The storyline of this game is downright outstanding, it truley shines in the market of todays games. This game also has some of the best voice acting, with popular voice actor Nolan North voicing the Rats.Now the physics, oh how great they are. I have never in my life seen a videogame with better physics than Bad Rats™, invent4 have really outdone themselves this gem.

Overall, Bad Rats™ is an absolutely fantastic game, I recommend  everyone tries this masterpiece. I give this game a 9/10

















Just kidding, this game sucks ♥♥♥♥ and I spent more time writing this stupid review than I did playing the game. 0/10 ♥♥♥♥ you.

reviewText:
Ignore my steam hours, thats not where my mind is in.
Bad Rats is a game which will and is already consider by a wide community, a masterpiece. Its inutive design and variation of both easy and tough was challenging to the point where i was forced to both tactically and strategically rethink my actions in the continuation of the game.
Through all this you really started to get this feeling for all the characters in the game as they were all easy to relate to our own time and society. Each with their own personality and unique character.
As to the story this was just pure gold, and will probabaly be remmebered through Video game as pure art and defenition of a game deserving a Game Of the Year award.
As this review draws to a close, and my indiction to return to playing bad rats I can personally say this is pure gold on the steam website. for only 0.99 I would rather pay 99.0$ for this if I could and help these superb developers in any way i could.
I am eagerly anticipating the next sequel to the Bad Rats which will hopefully, with these capable developers, be a successful franchise and bring us a next generation of RPG´s, FPS, and gameplay never seen on any platform before.
1/10 a masterpiece

reviewText: This game is the greatest piece of interactive art ever constructed on the face of this planet. It is unbearable to believe it only recieved a 9, it definitely deserved a 10, nay, an 11. The sheer emotion packed into the rats gets you so invested into the characters, such as the suicide bomber rat. The storyline was action-packed, well-delivered, and never misses a beat. The game is so full of detail, you could nearly smell the cheese emanting off of the rats. The atmosphere generated by this work of interactive art, is so full of life you wouldn't believe it was developed by such a small house. You will be sent on a roller coaster of emotions and sheer awe at the amazing skills put into this game blow your breath away. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText:
Bad Rats™ comes closer than any other game I have yet played to representing the complex situational challenges of making pizza.
It is a superb game that every serious gamer should definitely have in his or her stable.

Bad Rats™ has clearly been designed by a team with a deep understanding of guantanamo interrogation techniques and a passion for warcrimes and historical accuracy.
I can't praise the game highly enough and I can only say to those of you who have not yet purchased it, or who gave up on Bad Rats™ because it's harribul, that you are missing out on the opportunity to experience and contribute to the finest virus ever made.

Prettier than Kim Jong and better than Ebola 10/10- IGN

Please, spread the Rats™ and gift it to your Bad™ friends

PS: thanks to my friend madnesscats for gifting me this masterpiece of artwork, I'am not gonna lie, it changed my life foreva

reviewText: No. Okay? No. Not even for a dollar, not even for five cents. Not for the novelty of a bad game, not to see what could have been, not to see what the big joke is. Not in a car, not in the rain, not in the dark, not on a train. All the hee-larious 'positive' recommendations have actually skewed this unimaginable piece of crap to trend 'mostly positive' in the Steam reviews, and that's ridiculous. It's not even funny.\n\nI'm not going to speculate at length about whether the developers are horrible people or just inept and/or lazy, but this is not a good game. Go buy Contraption Maker, hell, go buy Crazy Machines, go buy literally any other Incredible Machine clone you can possibly find, but this one is not worth any amount of money. It is boring, broken, and unfunny. And that's the joke.

reviewText: Not terrible. This is basically a physics based puzzle game where rats take out their vengeance on cats in varied and unique ways. The music for the game sounds cool, the animation is good, the contraptions have cool and varied ways of accomplishing your goals, and in general, the game is actually not bad at all. Especially since you probably will own this regardless, either via gag gifts or because it often costs like 19 cents and offers trading cards. Whatever the reason you end up with this game (and you will, lol), you can at least get a little bit of fun out of it while farming for those cards.\n\nYou already own this (or will), so there isnt really a reason to rate this, but I think I will still give this six shaved cats with a variety of scars and missing limbs from explosions, axes, baseballs, and so on out of ten possible.

reviewText:
NOTE: This is a slightly shortened version of my review without screenshots. For the full review, please visit  Real Gamer Reviews[realgamerreviews.com]

The worst thing about this game, by far, is the overabundance of sarcastic reviews littered all over Steam from second-rate wannabe comedians. Please, guys. The joke is old. It's done. It's been made before. Please, let it go.

As for the game itself, my feelings are mixed. Make no doubt about it - the game is flawed. Very flawed. Overall I'd give it a 3.5/10. It had some potential but is very, very rough around the edges.

First things first - the gameplay. The gameplay will be very familiar to people that grew up playing The Incredible Machine. Also, to a lesser extent, it reminds me of Lemmings. You play as the rats, and the ultimate goal is to brutally murder the cat on each level by manipulating a ball. You get access to a number of different rats, depending on the level. Archer rat will shoot the ball straight ahead, vaccuum rat will suck the ball upwards, tractor rat will move the ball slowly forward, etc. You also get access to a few props per level, such as crates, wooden planks, balloons, etc. Once again, this will all be very familiar to The Incredible Machines veterans.

So what's the issue then, you ask? Firstly, probably the most game-breaking issue is the fact that the physics are inconsistent. You can position everything right, but when you press play"
date: things can still go wrong. Then you can try pressing play again 6 times and 6 different things will happen
recommended: even though you haven't moved any of your objects/rats. This is made even stupider by the fact that at the end of each level
hoursPlayed: you're able to view the "Original solution" (by the developers
voteText: presumably)
helpfulPercent: and when you hit "play" on those
votesHelpful: a good 50% or more will fail on the first try. Ultimately
votesTotal: it means that each time you create a setup for a level
votesFunny: you should hit play multiple times before changing anything. It's... silly. A game so reliant on physics should not have its physics randomised in this way.\n\nThe second gameplay issue is that a lot of the things in the game are clunky. With the wooden ramp
commentsCount: for example
column16: the game tries to angle it at an "ideal" angle depending on where you put it
column17: but this so-called ideal angle often isn't the angle you want it at
column18: and it's incredibly frustrating to try to lie a wooden plank flat when the game decides it wants to be at a 45 degree angle.\n\nThe third issue with the game itself is that it's the most unstable thing I've ever played in my life. I've played for a little over an hour and have had the game semi-crash on me 6 times. I say semi-crash

column21: it keeps me in the game but doesn't let me click on anything or scroll anywhere. It's possible that I've actually pressed something accidentally to cause this
column22: so if anyone has any insight on it

column24: given how much sense it would have made to have the game autosave at the end of each level. Fortunately
